Operating Procedures

For the purposes of safely conducting activities within plant processes, the Ammonia plant maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and startup.  Emergency shutdown procedures include the conditions under which emergency shutdown is required and the assignment of shutdown responsibility to qualified operators to ensure that an emergency shutdown is executed in a safe and timely manner.  Operating procedures are regularly reviewed, certified annually, and are readily accessible to those involved in operating and maintaining the process.

Training

The Ammonia plant has a comprehensive training program in place to conduct initial and refresher training for all personnel who operate and maintain a covered process.  Operations personnel are initially trained in assigned unit process overviews and operating procedures.  The training includes specific safety and health hazards, normal and emergency operations and safe work practices.  Operators receive classroom, field training, exercise and simulation training.  Operators are required to demonstrate their knowledge through tests, skill demonstrations and have adequate knowledge to perform job duties and tasks in a safe manner.  Refresher training is conducted at least every three years.  

Mechanical Integrity

The Ammonia plant carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program in place at the Nederland plant stationary source.

Process Safety Information

The Ammonia plant maintains a detailed record of safety information that includes information pertaining to the hazards of the hazardous chemicals, information pertaining to technology, and information pertaining to the equipment in the process.  Process Safety Information is readily available and is updated when changes are made in accordance with management of change procedures. Safety Data Sheets along other various technical documents are used to facilitate safe operation of the processes. The documents address limits for key process parameters, safe operating limits, chemical inventories, and equipment design basis.
 
Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)

The Ammonia plant conducts comprehensive PHAs to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are identified, risk ranked and controlled effectively. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is Hazard and Operability (HAZOP) and are supplemented by Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA). The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in PHA and LOPA methodology, engineering and process operations and will be revalidated every five years. Executive Summary

1. Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

We at the Woodside Energy - Beaumont New Ammonia plant in Nederland, Texas, are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at our facility. It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.

2. The Stationary Source and the Regulated Substances Handled

The Woodside Energy - Beaumont New Ammonia plant in Nederland is a hydrogen-based greenfield ammonia facility, which is expected to begin producing ammonia in 2025. The project is a collaboration between Woodside Energy and Linde that integrates Lindes low-carbon intensity hydrogen production and carbon capture technology with Woodside Energys ammonia production, storage and transportation infrastructure. Anhydrous Ammonia and the Synthesis Gas Flammable Mixture are the only two Risk Management Program (RMP) regulated substances present in the covered process above the threshold quantity (TQ) identified in the Environmental Protection Agencys (EPAs) RMP rule (40 CFR 68). Synthesis Gas is used in the loop section of the plant and is a combination of hydrogen, ammonia, and nitrogen with a CAT 4 flammability rating. Individually Hydrogen and natural gas (containing methane, ethane, propane, butane, and pentane) are also used in the ammonia product process but are not present in quantities that exceed the TQ.

3. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The Ammonia plant has developed an accidental release prevention program to comply with the requirements set out under the RMP rule. In addition, this program complies with the Occupational Safety and Health Administrations (OSHAs) P

Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at the Ammonia plant to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  All changes are systematically evaluated, documented, approved and implemented while minimizing risks and maintaining operational efficiency.  Employees involved in operating a process and maintenance whose job tasks will be affected by a change in the process are informed of, and trained in, the change prior to start-up of the process or affected part of the process.  If a change results in a change in the process safety information and/or an operating procedure, such information is updated.  

Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-start up safety review is required for new facility or modified plants prior to commissioning and prior to start up after a major maintenance turnaround or shutdown.  A PSSR is conducted to confirm that the required construction, modification or maintenance actions have been completed in accordance with design specifications and that all safety, operating, maintenance, reliability and emergency procedures are adequate and in place.  The PSSR must further confirm that recommendations from the various PHAs have been implemented, process safety information has been updated, and training completed.

Compliance Audits

The Ammonia plant conducts compliance audits at least every three years to verify that the procedures and practices developed under the RMP rule are adequate and are being followed.  The au

dit team consists of at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  Management shall promptly determine and document an appropriate response to each of the findings of the compliance audit, and document that deficiencies have been corrected. 

Incident Investigation

The Ammonia plant promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  Incident investigations are initiated as promptly as possible, but not later than 48 hours following the incident.  An incident investigation team is established and consists of at least one person knowledgeable in the process involved, including a contract employee if the incident involved work of the contractor, and other persons with appropriate knowledge and experience to thoroughly investigate and analyze the incident.  A tracking system is in place to promptly address and resolve the incident report findings and recommendations.  Resolutions and corrective actions are documented.  The report is reviewed with all affected personnel whose job tasks are relevant to the incident findings including contract employees where applicable. 

Employee Participation

The Ammonia plant believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  Examples of employee participation include involvement in safety committees, pre-startup safety reviews, process hazard analysis, job hazard analysis and procedure reviews.  Employees can also participate in the resolution of process hazard analysis, compliance audit and incident investigation recommendations and findings.  A system is in place for employees to anonymously report RMP-reportable accidents or other related RMP non-compliance issues.

Contractors

The Ammonia plant uses contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.

The following requirements apply to contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process: (1) Evaluating contractors safety performance and programs and ensuring qualified contractors are selected; (2) Ensuring contractors are trained in worksite safety and health hazards such as potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to their work and Ammonia processes; (3) Ensuring applicable provisions of the Emergency Response Plan are reviewed prior to commencement of work; (4) Ensuring contractors are familiar with the work practices which control the entrance, presence and exit from covered process areas; (5) Periodically evaluate the performance of contract employers in fulfilling their requirements; (6) Maintaining a contract employee injury and illness log related to the contractor's work in process areas.

Hot Work Permits

Hot work permits are issued for hot work operations conducted on or near unit processes.  The permit has an exhaustive list of all possible hot works with a step-by-step checklist or template for safe operations including the fire prevention and protection requirements to be implemented prior to beginning the hot work operations.  It also contains the date(s) authorized for hot work; and identifies the object on which hot work is to be performed.  Every worker should obtain a hot work permit and follow the steps before, during and after conducting any hot work. 

 4. Five-year Accident History

The Ammonia plant has procedures to investigate every incident thoroughly to determine ways to prevent similar incidents from occurring and to keep records of all incidents that occur at our facility. In accordance with the RMP rule, an accidental release must be included in the five-year accident history if it involves a regulated substance released from a covered process that results in death, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite de

aths, injuries, evacuations, shelter in place, property damage, or environmental damage. The Ammonia plant has had no accidental releases of regulated substances meeting the five-year accident history reporting criteria within the last 5-years.

5. Emergency Response Plan

The Ammonia plant has a written emergency action plan to prepare, train and respond to accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including (1) procedures for reporting a fire or other emergency, as well as procedures for emergency evacuation, including type of evacuation and exit route assignments, medical and rescue by appointed employees; (2) procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate critical plant operations before they evacuate; (3) procedure to account for all employees before and during evacuation; (4) notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.

6. Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The Ammonia plant strives to continually improve its safety program and to reward employees for outstanding safety performance.  The site has a Safety Committee that meets on a regular basis.  The Safety Committee is comprised of employees from all areas of the plant.  Lessons learned are held to present different safety topics to raise awareness. The site has continuous training in the Training Registration module within the company-wide HSE MESH system.  The assigned courses are sent out on a set frequency to the employees based on their job description.  Site wide safety drills are conducted to determine deficiencies and improvement opportunities.  Tabletop exercises are held internally and with neighboring and local LEPC.  The site has a system in place to notify the community should there be an off-site release.
